creditline: Gift of funds from the Ronald F. Kinney Foundation
description: portrait (head and torso) of a seated man with a short pointed beard and close cropped hair, wearing a black jacket, grey tie and vest and white shirt; man in left section of image, with black and grey patterned curtain behind his head; view over man's PL shoulder of room with black cat in LRC, pictures frames on wall, and sculpture, plants and other objects on a table; room in pastel colors
inscription:
Signature, Edition, Inscription and Stamp

see Signed; bottom center, in pencil: [ar]; on back, in pencil: [98.0.75]
markings: LLC, impressed in paper: L\'Estampe originale publisher\'s chop
provenance: Private collection, France; [Eric G. Carlson Fine Prints & Drawings, New York, 2012; sold to MIA]
signed: LRC, in the image: [Eug Delatre (very light--in reverse)]; LRC below image, in blue: [Eug Delatre / No. 42]
text:
Eugène Delâtre was a French printmaker and watercolorist best known for his color intaglio prints of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. He was first recognized for his artistic prowess during the 1890s, when he contributed plates to such important French publications as "L'Estampe originale" (1893-95) and "L'Estampe moderne" (1897-99). Together with artists such as Theodore Roussel, Mary Cassatt, Manuel Robbe, and Jean Francois Raffaelli, Delâtre helped revitalize color etching in France both as a creative artist and as a specialist printer.
This portrait is of the French Decadent poet and novelist Joris-Karl Huysmans (1848–1907) in his writing studio. Huysmans is best known today for his controversial 1884 novel A Rebours (Against Nature), sometimes called the bible of decadence.
title: Portrait of Huysmans
